image.altText: A close up image of a woman with an unidentified child

items.synopsis: The suspected murder of Perth mother Georgia Lyall, believed by police to be at the hands of her ex-partner, leaves those who knew her grieving and in disbelief.

title.children: 'You deserved so much more than this': Tributes flow for victim of suspected murder-suicide

image.altText: Caboolture plane crash

items.synopsis: A man and a woman have died after a collision between two aircraft at Caboolture Airfield.

title.children: Investigation launched after mid-air collision leaves two dead north of Brisbane

image.altText: An aerial view of streets in suburban Melbourne, on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Some suburbs are now seeing as much as a 14.4 per cent growth in median house value.

title.children: Some Australian suburbs are experiencing another property market boom. Is yours one of them?

image.altText: A woman looks through bags and baskets in the boot of her car.

items.synopsis: As the WA electorate of Rockingham votes for Mark McGowan's replacement, there's hope his successor will tackle the city's growing housing and homelessness issue.

title.children: 'There's a big divide': Will the homelessness crisis in Rockingham affect how it votes in by-election?

image.altText: A row of heavily armed men in camo gear, carrying guns

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin's attempted mutiny last month might have failed in Russia, but in Mali and a handful of other African nations, the Wagner Group's influence — and reign of terror — is expanding.

title.children: Over five horrific days, armed Russian mercenaries tortured an African town. Is this Wagner's future?

image.altText: A man in a hair salon chair holds up dreadlocks that have been cut off.

items.synopsis: Christopher Mark Jordan, 36, appears in a Launceston court accused of murdering a Tasmanian teen after the discovery of human remains in bushland this week.

title.children: Man accused of murdering teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell named in first court appearance

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up his ballot while voting in the election that makes him the prime minister

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will further escalate a high-stakes political stand-off with the Greens, in a move that could send Australians to an early, double-dissolution election.

title.children: PM stepping closer to early election trigger as housing battle with Greens escalates

image.altText: Image of prison buildings behind a high razor-wire security fence

items.synopsis: A severe housing shortage in the Pilbara is escalating tensions at Roebourne Regional Prison, according to the state's prison officers union.

title.children: Housing crisis exacerbates staff shortage, creating 'volatile' situation at regional WA jail

image.altText: Aerial view of the Port Arthur historic site, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: A research paper finds World Heritage sites, protected for their unique natural or cultural values, are under extreme threat from climate change and risk being de-listed if those values are eroded.

title.children: 'Water is getting into these buildings': Sea level rises are hurting our World Heritage sites, research finds

image.altText: Girl in silhouette watches sunset from rocks

items.synopsis: The United Nations secretary-general delivers a dramatic speech warning the heatwaves searing much of the northern hemisphere have been a "disaster" for the planet. An emerging El Niño means it may be just the start.

title.children: United Nations warns of 'global boiling' as July set to shatter heat records

image.altText: Lloyd Austin and Rchard Marle at a press conference.

items.synopsis: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken are here for meetings with their counterparts ahead of joint AUSMIN talks that are likely to feature climate change, regional geopolitics, AUKUS and expanding defence ties between Australia and the United States.

title.children: US defense secretary accuses China of 'bullying behaviour' ahead of high-level talks in Brisbane

image.altText: Seal spotted in Gold Coast lake

items.synopsis: The Glitter Strip is well-known for its dark underbelly and criminal probes, but a different kind of investigation is underway on the Gold Coast after a fur seal was spotted on the loose in the city.

title.children: Investigators work to crack mystery of how fur seal ended up in Gold Coast lake

image.altText: An image of Sydney's CBD, with people walking, faces not visible, carrying shopping bags.

items.synopsis: The odds of the Reserve Bank increasing interest rates at its meeting next week have fallen off the back of weaker than expected retail sales figures, while the US economy grew by 2 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Chances of an RBA rate rise next week fall as retail sales dive, ASX slides

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Amongst all the speculation of what our own central bank might do next week, the Bank of Japan has kept its interest rates low at its meeting today — but it's also flagged that it could make its policy more flexible. Japan's central bank uses yield curve control (YCC), which requires them to target a longer-term interest rate. To achieve that, they buy and sell bonds as they required in order to reach that target rate. After its meeting, the BOJ kept its short-term interest rate target unchanged at -0.1%, and its 10-year government bond yield around 0%. The BoJ also maintained its guidance allowing the 10-year yield to move 0.5% around the 0% target, but that would be "references" instead of "rigid limits". Carol Kong, currency strategist at Commonwealth Bank said the trading range shift would offer more flexibility. "The BOJ will now regard the upper and lower bounds of the 10-year JGB trading range as 'references, not as rigid limits', allowing for more flexibility," she said. "But the YCC change looks purely technical. "The statement continued to strike a dovish tone with the BOJ still forecasting below-target inflation in fiscal years 2024 and 2025. So, no signal of policy tightening over the forecast horizon."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of Japan keeps interest rates low but flags more flexible policy

children.content: Amongst all the speculation of what our own central bank might do next week, the
Bank of Japan has kept its interest rates low
at its meeting today — but it's also flagged that it could make its policy more flexible.

Japan's central bank uses yield curve control (YCC), which requires them to target a longer-term interest rate. To achieve that, they buy and sell bonds as they required in order to reach that target rate.
After its meeting, the BOJ kept its
short-term interest rate target unchanged at -0.1%
, and its 10-year government bond yield around 0%.
The BoJ also maintained its guidance allowing the 10-year yield to move 0.5% around the 0% target, but that would be
"references" instead of "rigid limits"
Carol Kong, currency strategist at Commonwealth Bank said the trading range shift would offer more flexibility.
"The BOJ will now regard the upper and lower bounds of the 10-year JGB trading range as 'references, not as rigid limits', allowing for more flexibility," she said.
"But the YCC change looks purely technical.
"The statement
continued to strike a dovish tone
with the BOJ still forecasting below-target inflation in fiscal years 2024 and 2025. So, no signal of policy tightening over the forecast horizon."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we heard about the 34% rise in complaints made to the financial ombudsman in the last financial year as more people experience financial stress. The Australian Financial Complaints Authority (AFCA) says the current environment has created "a perfect storm" for consumer complaints, because of the current cost of living pressures facing households. AFCA boss David Locke told ABC News Breakfast that there's also been a 57% increase in complaints about buy now, pay later providers, with more people relying on them to pay for essentials. He also said the rise in scams is also causing people to lose "a lot of money", on top of problems with insurance claims and delays in handling too. You can watch his full chat on the News Breakfast couch with Michael Rowland and Lisa Millar below — and he also included some tips on how those with financial disputes can try and get them resolved.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A 'perfect storm' is driving a rise in financial and banking complaints, AFCA says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has shed 1% to 7,378 points as of 1:25pm AEST, but still looks on track to finish the week higher. All sectors are firmly in the red, with the exception of energy which has picked up a modest 0.1%. Real estate has shed the most, down 2.4%, while basic materials are down 1.9%, and industrials have dipped by 1.1%. And while the ASX is sinking at the moment, it remains on track to finish higher for the week and is still in with a shot of closing up by 1.1% — which would make it the third straight week it's gained. As for the top five movers : Insignia Financial +2.4% BlueScope Steel +1.1% Megaport +1% Chorus +1% Breville +0.9% And the bottom five movers : Capricorn Metals -10.1% Regis Resources -8% Perpetual -7.9% Perseus Mining -6.9% West African Resources -6.7%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX sinks but remains on track to finish higher for the week
